item.title: “Every media era gets the fabulists it deserves”
item.description: Back in August, the Press Gazette’s Charlotte Tobitt reported that Wired and Business Insider had taken down AI-generated articles by a “freelancer” named “Margaux Blanchard.” It was a case study of a particularly modern problem: scammers using AI to fool editors into publishing complete fabrications, the kind of thing that until recently belonged in the...

item.title: UC to keep postdoctoral hiring incentive program it previously said would be cut
item.description: The UC will continue offering hiring incentives for a more than 40-year-old postdoctoral fellowship program, despite previously announcing it would end the initiative. The President’s Postdoctoral Fellowship Program awards a nearly $75,000 salary to about 30 scholars across the UC for research conducted under faculty sponsorship.
item.source:markdown: The UC will continue offering hiring incentives for a more than 40-year-old postdoctoral fellowship program, despite previously announcing it would end the initiative. The President’s Postdoctoral Fellowship Program awards a nearly $75,000 salary to about 30 scholars across the UC for research conducted under faculty sponsorship.

item.title: USAC passes resolution asserting UCLA must better support parenting students
item.description: The Undergraduate Students Association Council passed a resolution alleging UCLA does not adequately support parenting students. The resolution, which was passed Sept. 30, claims UCLA violated California Assembly Bill 79 and Assembly Bill 1326 by not employing a designated California Work Opportunity and Responsibility to Kids liaison to proactively engage with student-parents.
item.source:markdown: The Undergraduate Students Association Council passed a resolution alleging UCLA does not adequately support parenting students. The resolution, which was passed Sept. 30, claims UCLA violated California Assembly Bill 79 and Assembly Bill 1326 by not employing a designated California Work Opportunity and Responsibility to Kids liaison to proactively engage with student-parents.

item.title: Opinion: Student researchers need to stand up for themselves politically
item.description: The Trump administration’s policies leave a lasting imprint on universities across the country — and UCLA has not been spared. With continual threats to scholarly autonomy, academics must become more politically engaged to safeguard progress.

item.title: HOOLIGAN Theatre Company performs ‘Carrie: The Musical’ Dec. 6, 7
item.description: HOOLIGAN Theatre Company is out for pig’s blood in its production of “Carrie: The Musical.” In the stage adaptation of author Stephen King’s debut novel “Carrie,” Protagonist Carrie White, a seventeen-year-old girl facing religious abuse, discovers her telekinetic abilities and – after being doused in pig’s blood at her senior prom – murders her fellow classmates.

item.title: UCLA to face Sacramento State in LA matchup, building from past blunders
item.description: Adversity breeds struggle. But struggle cultivates growth. After No. 19 UCLA men’s basketball’s (3-1) first loss of the season to then-No. 5 Arizona at the Intuit Dome – a game they led by 10 in the first half and eight with under six minutes remaining – it will have the chance to bounce back against Sacramento State (3-2) Tuesday night at Pauley Pavilion.
item.source:markdown: Adversity breeds struggle. But struggle cultivates growth. After No. 19 UCLA men’s basketball’s (3-1) first loss of the season to then-No. 5 Arizona at the Intuit Dome – a game they led by 10 in the first half and eight with under six minutes remaining – it will have the chance to bounce back against Sacramento State (3-2) Tuesday night at Pauley Pavilion.

item.description: Devon Young, a second-year mathematics student, said she has noticed food options on the Hill have been more limited since the start of the strikes, causing uncertainty concerning what times the dining halls are open.  She said while she finds the strikes understandable, she is not sure whether they will inspire change.

item.description: At 11:25 a.m., AFSCME Local 3299 demonstrators stopped in front of the Meyer and Renee Luskin Conference Center, where the UC Board of Regents is meeting Tuesday to Thursday, chanting, “UC, UC, you can’t hide, we can see your greedy side” and “UC Regents, listen up.” Two Contemporary Services Corporation officers blocked the side entrance of the Luskin Conference Center following the demonstrators’ arrival.
item.source:markdown: At 11:25 a.m., AFSCME Local 3299 demonstrators stopped in front of the Meyer and Renee Luskin Conference Center, where the UC Board of Regents is meeting Tuesday to Thursday, chanting, “UC, UC, you can’t hide, we can see your greedy side” and “UC Regents, listen up.” Two Contemporary Services Corporation officers blocked the side entrance of the Luskin Conference Center following the demonstrators’ arrival.

item.description: Celeste Rodriguez, a California state assemblymember for the 43rd District, said it is important to stand in solidarity with workers. “They (union members) want to make sure that people understand that an investment in them and their contracts for fair wages and opportunities is really investment in the surrounding community,” she said.
item.source:markdown: Celeste Rodriguez, a California state assemblymember for the 43rd District, said it is important to stand in solidarity with workers. “They (union members) want to make sure that people understand that an investment in them and their contracts for fair wages and opportunities is really investment in the surrounding community,” she said.

item.description: Michael Avant, the president of AFSCME Local 3299, said that since union members’ contracts expired in July 2024 and October 2024, workers have lived “paycheck to paycheck,” struggling to pay rent and purchase groceries.

item.title: Album review: Summer Walker’s ‘Finally Over It’ ends trilogy of albums in lackluster manner
item.description: Summer Walker is closing a chapter in her career with another confessional album. The R&B singer-songwriter’s third LP, “Finally Over It,” released Nov. 14, arrived as the final entry in a trilogy that includes her 2019 debut “Over It” and her 2021 sophomore album “Still Over It.” The new project spans 55 minutes of music across 18 tracks, split evenly between two discs with the first nine songs labeled “For Better” and the second half called “For Worse.” While Walker’s honest lyrics remain engaging across the LP over a variety of nostalgic R&B beats, the overabundance of 13 guest appearances never produces a collaboration on par with her best work.
item.source:markdown: Summer Walker is closing a chapter in her career with another confessional album. The R&B singer-songwriter’s third LP, “Finally Over It,” released Nov. 14, arrived as the final entry in a trilogy that includes her 2019 debut “Over It” and her 2021 sophomore album “Still Over It.” The new project spans 55 minutes of music across 18 tracks, split evenly between two discs with the first nine songs labeled “For Better” and the second half called “For Worse.” While Walker’s honest lyrics remain engaging across the LP over a variety of nostalgic R&B beats, the overabundance of 13 guest appearances never produces a collaboration on par with her best work.

item.title: Daily student parking permits to be ‘significantly limited’ beginning January 2026
item.description: UCLA student daily parking permits will be “significantly limited” – and on some days may not be offered at all – starting Jan. 1, 2026. Student daily parking permits, which currently cost $7.28 per day, have been offered since April 2022 as a use for excess post-pandemic parking capacity, a UCLA Transportation spokesperson said in an emailed statement.

item.title: Julio Frenk announces Executive Budget Action Group to manage UCLA’s monetary concerns
item.description: This post was updated Nov. 12 at 2:38 p.m. UCLA is launching a new leadership coalition to manage the university’s budgetary shortfall amid state and federal funding cuts, Chancellor Julio Frenk announced in a Wednesday campuswide email.  Frenk, who will chair the Executive Budget Action Group, said in the email that the group’s creation was prompted by “structural budget deficits, federal and state funding uncertainties, and rising costs,” which challenge the university’s academic mission.  The budget action group will create guidelines for future campus financial decisions, investigate specific areas for improvement in its investments and emphasize transparency in all of its budgetary decisions, Frenk said in the email.  “Our North Star is to ensure that the resources entrusted to us add maximum value back to society while protecting the academic core that defines UCLA’s strength,” he said.  The California State Legislature and Gov.
item.source:markdown: _This post was updated Nov. 12 at 2:38 p.m._ UCLA is launching a new leadership coalition to manage the university’s budgetary shortfall amid state and federal funding cuts, Chancellor Julio Frenk announced in a Wednesday campuswide email. Frenk, who will chair the Executive Budget Action Group, said in the email that the group’s creation was prompted by “structural budget deficits, federal and state funding uncertainties, and rising costs,” which challenge the university’s academic mission. The budget action group will create guidelines for future campus financial decisions, investigate specific areas for improvement in its investments and emphasize transparency in all of its budgetary decisions, Frenk said in the email. “Our North Star is to ensure that the resources entrusted to us add maximum value back to society while protecting the academic core that defines UCLA’s strength,” he said. item.title: UCLA hosts Exploring Your Universe, an interactive science fair for LA community
item.description: UCLA’s Court of Sciences teemed with activity Sunday as about 12,000 people attended the university’s largest annual science fair. item.title: CA Supreme Court reaffirms UC cannot bar undocumented students from on-campus jobs
item.description: The California Supreme Court stood by a lower court’s ruling that the UC cannot bar undocumented students from holding on-campus jobs Oct. 29. A lawsuit alleged that the UC’s rule preventing undocumented students from working on-campus jobs violates the California Fair Employment and Housing Act – which says that it is illegal for employers to discriminate against employees or applicants on the basis of their immigration status – according to court documents.
item.source:markdown: The California Supreme Court stood by a lower court’s ruling that the UC cannot bar undocumented students from holding on-campus jobs Oct. 29. item.title: UCLA football will jump into the unknown in upcoming Nebraska matchup
item.description: They do not know what they’re facing. And that is the point. item.title: No Money
The Sundial Magazine, October 2025
Report urges Westwood Village to expand commercial appeal beyond students
item.description: Westwood has a problem with its “overly student-centric identity,” a consulting group told the Westwood Village Improvement Association in June. A report published this June by Anderson Strategy Group urged the association to lean away from student attraction, and make Westwood appeal to a broader audience, including families, residents and tourists, as well as address vacancy issues.

item.title: Student organization coalition files amicus brief supporting lawsuit against Trump
item.description: This post was updated Nov. 5 at 1:02 a.m. A coalition of 25 student organizations filed an amicus brief Thursday in support of a lawsuit against President Donald Trump that alleged research funding suspensions to UCLA and subsequent settlement demands violated employees’ free speech.  The student organizations – filing under the name Students for Higher Education – said in the brief that the federal government’s “ruinous cuts to federal research funding,” its $1.2 billion settlement demand and attacks on international students obstruct the constitutionally protected free speech of students and faculty members.
item.source:markdown: _This post was updated Nov. 5 at 1:02 a.m._ A coalition of 25 student organizations filed an amicus brief Thursday in support of a lawsuit against President Donald Trump that alleged research funding suspensions to UCLA and subsequent settlement demands violated employees’ free speech. The student organizations – filing under the name Students for Higher Education – said in the brief that the federal government’s “ruinous cuts to federal research funding,” its $1.2 billion settlement demand and attacks on international students obstruct the constitutionally protected free speech of students and faculty members.

item.title: Former UCLA Labor Center director, workers’ rights advocate Kent Wong dies at 69
item.description: Kent Wong, the former director of the UCLA Labor Center and an advocate for workers’ rights, died Oct. 8. He was 69 years old. Wong was the director of the UCLA Labor Center from 1991 to 2023, during which he oversaw the 2021 development of its new MacArthur Park headquarters, said Toby Higbie, a professor of history and labor studies.
item.source:markdown: Kent Wong, the former director of the UCLA Labor Center and an advocate for workers’ rights, died Oct. 8. He was 69 years old. item.title: UC Investments offers $2.4 billion for stake in new Big Ten entity
item.description: UC Investments offered $2.4 billion for a 10% stake in a new entity that would manage the Big Ten’s league-wide media rights and sponsorship deals. item.title: Men’s basketball’s Steven Jamerson II leaves his comfort zone, proves resilience
item.description: Basketball coaches often prioritize teaching their pupils how to pivot with the ball.
